datafield.subfield: The current News-Leader [LCCN: sn78002171] published in Fernandina, Florida bills itself as "Florida's oldest weekly newspaper." The News-Leader traces its lineage back to the original Fernandina (FL) News [LCCN: sn95026700], a semiweekly and sometimes triweekly edited by S.W. Manucy from 1894 to 1896. Manucy, by the turn of the 20th century, would also serve as Nassau County (FL) Assessor of Taxes. The Fernandina News, edited by Manucy, continued as simply the News [LCCN: sn95047163] until 1910. It then merged with the Fernandina (FL) Record [LCCN: sn95026708] (published from 1907 to 1910) to become the Fernandina (FL) News-Record [LCCN: sn95026702], continuing under this title until 1920. Another merger in 1920 yielded the Nassau County (FL) Leader and Fernandina News-Record [LCCN: sn95026704]. This long title was shortened, in 1925, to the Nassau County (FL) Leader [LCCN: sn95026701], which published until 1939 when the paper's name reverted to Fernandina News [LCCN: sn95047162], now edited by Howard Davis. In the late 1940s, the Fernandina News became the Fernandina (FL) News-Leader [LCCN: sn95026705] and subsequently the Fernandina Beach (FL) News-Leader [LCCN: sn95026706]. The Fernandina Beach News-Leader was a weekly, published from 1959 until 1980 by John H. Perry and edited by E.R. Maples. In 1980, the newspaper became known simply as the News-Leader. Present day Fernandina Beach, Florida sits along the north-eastern boundary of the states of Florida and Georgia on Amelia Island (FL) at the mouth of the St. Marys River in Nassau County. By the turn of the 20th century, Fernandina had been transformed from a garrison town during the Seminole and Civil Wars to a first stop in Florida for northern tourists. Its economy, between 1898 and 1902, was bolstered also by the Spanish American War and the Cuban Revolution against colonial Spain in particular. While Fernandina would retain its gateway status for much of the first decade of the 20th century, its star would begin to fade with the reconstruction of Jacksonville (FL) in the wake of the Great Fire of 1901 and the subsequent opening of the Port of Jacksonville in the deep waters of the St. Johns River to the south of Nassau County.--E. Kesse, University of Florida Digital Library Center.
